Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Right Common Carotid Artery Cannulation in Elective Aortic Surgery

Participants.evidence: 343 patients who underwent elective ascending aortic or aortic arch surgery

Intervention.evidence: One hundred procedures used the right CCA as the sole arterial cannulation site under moderate hypothermic circulatory arrest (MHCA).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the long-term outcomes of right common carotid artery (CCA) cannulation using a side graft for unilateral selective antegrade cerebral perfusion (uSACP).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative death from neurological causes, measured over a median follow-up of 5.4 years.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 343 patients who underwent elective ascending aortic or aortic arch surgery

Result_Outcome.evidence: After a median follow-up of 5.4 years, seven patients suffered a stroke, with a 92% survival rate at 6 years, comparable to an age- and gender-matched general population (log-rank P=0.50).

Harms.evidence: The early mortality and stroke rates were 1% and 4%, respectively.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was registered in the German clinical trials register.
